newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - July 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - July 11.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Friday:
* R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co, of RJR Nabisco, said it will retire the advertising image of Joe Camel.
* The Clinton administration will report to Congress on Friday that the North American Free Trade Agreement has so far generated modest benefits for the United States.
* Assets in stock, bond and money market mutual funds topped $4 trillion in June for the first time.
* The arrival of a heat wave lifted apparel sales and helped retailers report strong sales for June.
* Lower revenue from bond trading cut quarterly earnings at J.P. Morgan by 15 percent, but revenues rose.
* Compaq reported earnings that beat estimates and announced price cuts.
* The resignation of the Apple Computer CEO leaves an opening unlikely to attract many resumes.
* As New York State's utility industry braces for deregulation, a debate has begun over the role of the New York Power Authority.

* Some diet centers that had hoped prescription diet pills would provide a quick fix for their sagging sales are reconsidering their positions on dispensing the medications after a combination of two such drugs was linked to a heart ailment.

* Customers of Niagara Mohawk Power could have reduced rates by early next year as a result of an agreement that allows it to renegotiate its high-cost contracts for electricity with most of its independent power producers.
* Parts of tape recordings in a Texaco race discrimination case may have been erased.
* Palladium prices fell four percent after Russian exports resumed for the first time this year, ending an impasse that depleted stockpiles.
